document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Mathematics

BCB5E370DFE70131135A68A86D17958E.description: distinguish between wants and needs and identify income as a source to meet one's wants and needs.

BCB5A2E0DFE70131135968A86D17958E.description: list simple skills required for jobs; and

BCB56340DFE70131135868A86D17958E.description: differentiate between money received as income and money received as gifts;

BCB4D950DFE70131135668A86D17958E.description: Personal financial literacy. The student applies mathematical process standards to manage one's financial resources effectively for lifetime financial security. The student is expected to:

BCB48A70DFE70131135568A86D17958E.description: draw conclusions from real-object and picture graphs.

BCB43CE0DFE70131135468A86D17958E.description: use data to create real-object and picture graphs; and

BCB3F2C0DFE70131135368A86D17958E.description: collect, sort, and organize data into two or three categories;

BCB3AB70DFE70131135268A86D17958E.description: Data analysis. The student applies mathematical process standards to collect and organize data to make it useful for interpreting information. The student is expected to:

BCB35C80DFE70131135168A86D17958E.description: compare two objects with a common measurable attribute to see which object has more of/less of the attribute and describe the difference.

BCB30EE0DFE70131135068A86D17958E.description: give an example of a measurable attribute of a given object, including length, capacity, and weight; and

BCB2C290DFE70131134F68A86D17958E.description: Geometry and measurement. The student applies mathematical process standards to directly compare measurable attributes. The student is expected to:

BCB283B0DFE70131134E68A86D17958E.description: create two-dimensional shapes using a variety of materials and drawings.

BCB24260DFE70131134D68A86D17958E.description: classify and sort a variety of regular and irregular two- and three-dimensional figures regardless of orientation or size; and

BCB1F530DFE70131134C68A86D17958E.description: identify attributes of two-dimensional shapes using informal and formal geometric language interchangeably;

BCB194E0DFE70131134B68A86D17958E.description: identify two-dimensional components of three-dimensional objects;

BCB14460DFE70131134A68A86D17958E.description: identify three-dimensional solids, including cylinders, cones, spheres, and cubes, in the real world;

BCB0E810DFE70131134968A86D17958E.description: identify two-dimensional shapes, including circles, triangles, rectangles, and squares as special rectangles;

BCB09770DFE70131134868A86D17958E.description: Geometry and measurement. The student applies mathematical process standards to analyze attributes of two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional solids to develop generalizations about their properties. The student is expected to:

1A7DE44C0549482FAED5C802DE106555.description: Algebraic reasoning. The student applies mathematical process standards to identify the pattern in the number word list. The student is expected to recite numbers up to at least 100 by ones and tens beginning with any given number.

F191C551B61B4B76BE94457CAD655EBB.description: Number and operations. The student applies mathematical process standards to identify coins in order to recognize the need for monetary transactions. The student is expected to identify U.S. coins by name, including pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters.

BCB03FB0DFE70131134768A86D17958E.description: explain the strategies used to solve problems involving adding and subtracting within 10 using spoken words, concrete and pictorial models, and number sentences.

BCAFFD50DFE70131134668A86D17958E.description: solve word problems using objects and drawings to find sums up to 10 and differences within 10; and

BCAFB770DFE70131134568A86D17958E.description: model the action of joining to represent addition and the action of separating to represent subtraction;

BCAF7260DFE70131134468A86D17958E.description: Number and operations. The student applies mathematical process standards to develop an understanding of addition and subtraction situations in order to solve problems. The student is expected to:

BCAF2070DFE70131134368A86D17958E.description: compose and decompose numbers up to 10 with objects and pictures.

BCAED0C0DFE70131134268A86D17958E.description: use comparative language to describe two numbers up to 20 presented as written numerals; and

BCAE8170DFE70131134168A86D17958E.description: compare sets of objects up to at least 20 in each set using comparative language;

BCAE3370DFE70131134068A86D17958E.description: generate a number that is one more than or one less than another number up to at least 20;

BCADF340DFE70131133F68A86D17958E.description: generate a set using concrete and pictorial models that represents a number that is more than, less than, and equal to a given number up to 20;

BCADB110DFE70131133E68A86D17958E.description: recognize instantly the quantity of a small group of objects in organized and random arrangements;

BCAD6700DFE70131133D68A86D17958E.description: count a set of objects up to at least 20 and demonstrate that the last number said tells the number of objects in the set regardless of their arrangement or order;

BCAD28B0DFE70131133C68A86D17958E.description: read, write, and represent whole numbers from 0 to at least 20 with and without objects or pictures;

BCACE990DFE70131133B68A86D17958E.description: count forward and backward to at least 20 with and without objects;

BCACA5D0DFE70131133A68A86D17958E.description: Number and operations. The student applies mathematical process standards to understand how to represent and compare whole numbers, the relative position and magnitude of whole numbers, and relationships within the numeration system. The student is expected to:

BCAC5FA0DFE70131133968A86D17958E.description: display, explain, and justify mathematical ideas and arguments using precise mathematical language in written or oral communication.

BCABF8A0DFE70131133868A86D17958E.description: analyze mathematical relationships to connect and communicate mathematical ideas; and

BCABA100DFE70131133768A86D17958E.description: create and use representations to organize, record, and communicate mathematical ideas;

BCAB6460DFE70131133668A86D17958E.description: communicate mathematical ideas, reasoning, and their implications using multiple representations, including symbols, diagrams, graphs, and language as appropriate;

BCAB26F0DFE70131133568A86D17958E.description: select tools, including real objects, manipulatives, paper and pencil, and technology as appropriate, and techniques, including mental math, estimation, and number sense as appropriate, to solve problems;

BCAAE9B0DFE70131133468A86D17958E.description: use a problem-solving model that incorporates analyzing given information, formulating a plan or strategy, determining a solution, justifying the solution, and evaluating the problem-solving process and the reasonableness of the solution;

BCAAAD30DFE70131133368A86D17958E.description: apply mathematics to problems arising in everyday life, society, and the workplace;

BCAA6D00DFE70131133268A86D17958E.description: Mathematical process standards. The student uses mathematical processes to acquire and demonstrate mathematical understanding. The student is expected to:
